title: 108_s1915
content: Section 301(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include calculations for the impact of the resolution on the Government's overall liabilities and commitments over a 75-year and indefinite time horizon, using specified methodology from title 31, United States Code. Point of order established against legislation affecting government's overall liabilities and commitments. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include calculations on the impact of any measure with adverse effects exceeding 0.25 percent of future payroll taxes over 75 years or an indefinite period. The methods used for calculations must align with those in the financial statement under section 331(e) of title 31, United States Code. Any changes in direct spending or revenues that negatively impact the government's overall liabilities and commitments are not allowed in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The House of Representatives and the Senate are prohibited from passing legislation that would have a significant adverse impact on the government's overall liabilities and commitments. This includes any changes in direct spending or revenues that exceed 1.25 percent of the present discounted value of all future payrolls over a 75-year period or an indefinite time horizon. The calculations must assume the legislative measure will be a permanent change in law and disregard any adjustments or mechanisms that increase the government's liabilities. Section 904 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include references to section 312(g) in subsections (c)(1) and (d)(2). SEC. 9. TRUSTEES REPORT OF LIABILITIES. Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to require the Trustees to calculate the present value of projected benefits to current participants, minus projected revenues and trust fund balances. This includes reporting on the Closed Group Unfunded Obligation and emphasizing it in annual reports on Trust Fund solvency. The amendment to Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act requires the inclusion of annual changes in the Closed Group Unfunded Obligation in federal budgetary reports. The Treasury Department will analyze the present value of tax provisions. The Secretary of Treasury will analyze the net present value of specific tax provisions, while the President will calculate the impact on the government's overall liabilities and commitments over 75 years and beyond for tax expenditures exceeding 1.25% of future payrolls. The net present value is calculated for tax provisions exceeding 1.25% of future payrolls over 75 years and an indefinite time horizon. SEC. 11 prohibits the use of expedited procedures to pass legislation that worsens the budget deficit or reduces the surplus. It also limits reconciliation bills that increase the deficit or reduce the surplus. SEC. 12 reinstates the PAYGO enforcement. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a provision that applies unless a declaration of war is in effect. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will adjust direct spending and receipts legislation for fiscal year 2003 accordingly. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a Pay-As-You-Go Rule in Congress, which prohibits any legislation that would decrease the on-budget surplus, increase the on-budget deficit, or cause an on-budget deficit for specific time periods. The Pay-As-You-Go Rule in Congress prohibits direct-spending legislation that affects spending as defined by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The Pay-As-You-Go Rule in Congress prohibits direct-spending legislation that affects spending as defined by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Exclusions include concurrent resolutions on the budget and provisions affecting deposit insurance guarantee commitments. Calculations must use the baseline from the most recent concurrent resolution on the budget. The Pay-As-You-Go Rule in Congress prohibits direct-spending legislation that affects spending as defined by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Exclusions include concurrent resolutions on the budget and provisions affecting deposit insurance guarantee commitments. Calculations must use the baseline from the most recent concurrent resolution on the budget. If direct spending or revenue legislation decreases the on-budget surplus or increases the deficit, it must also do so when combined with all other legislation enacted since. The Pay-As-You-Go Rule in Congress prohibits direct spending legislation that affects spending. Exclusions include concurrent resolutions on the budget and provisions affecting deposit insurance guarantee commitments. Waivers require a three-fifths vote in the Senate. Appeals are limited to 1 hour and require a three-fifths vote to sustain. The Chair's ruling on a point of order under this subsection is determined by the Committee on the Budget. The subsection does not apply in fiscal years with a declaration of war.
